data.title: On the run with OneRepublic
data.meta_description: You probably need to be a bit of a gazelle if you are running with a rock and roll band on a two-year tour.
data.text:
Reviews and recommendations are unbiased and products are independently selected. Postmedia may earn an affiliate commission from purchases made through links on this page.

Article content

You probably need to be a bit of a gazelle if you are running with a rock and roll band on a two-year tour.

So perhaps it’s fitting for OneRepublic’s Brent Kutzle that an artist has captured his essence as a gazelle on the album cover for the band’s third record, Native.

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Try refreshing your browser, or

tap here to see other videos from our team.

On the run with OneRepublic Back to video

Each band member, in fact, is represented by a different creature.

“We hired this creative director for that album to do the art and he hung out with us one day. He called Ryan (Tedder, OneRepublic’s frontman) the next day and he said, ‘I know exactly what to do here. I’m going to put a bunch of different animals that don’t belong together (on the cover) because you guys are completely different personalities. You guys would not be hanging out if you weren’t in the band,’ ” Kutzle, who is the group’s bass and cello player, said in an interview in advance of their concert April 21 at Canadian Tire Centre.

Article content

“He asked Ryan (who is represented by a fox on the cover), ‘Who do you think each person is?’ and when Ryan got to me, he said, ‘He’s a kind of skittish dude if you lunge toward him. He’ll just freak out.’ So I guess I qualify as a gazelle. I could have been a giraffe. That would have fit too.”

Kutzle, a classically trained cellist, might seem an odd fit for a mainstream rock band like OneRepublic. But as he tells it, it was sort of a natural evolution.

His parents taught classical piano and he and his sister began piano lessons at age four or five in Orange County, California.

“Every day before and after school we were forced to sit in the hot seat and practise. When I was about 10, my parents said it was time to learn a string instrument — my sister was playing violin at the time. They decided cello because they didn’t see any other kids playing the cello. They said, ‘You’re going to have a career playing cello some day.’

“I hit it pretty hard for a while,” he said, citing the legendary Pablo Casals as his idol and Camille Saint-Saens’ The Swan as one of his favourite pieces. But by junior high school, “I was getting into bands and I started realizing that was a lot more fun.”

Advertisement 3

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Kutzle found writing his own music more interesting than playing off the page. He picked up the bass guitar and really has never looked back.

That doesn’t mean the cello was abandoned. He plays an indestructible black carbon-fibre model on tour, and he spends about a third of his time on stage with a bow in his hand. And like many cellists, he’s had a couple of them stolen. One that was worth about $10,000 was taken from the family garage. A second was pinched at a concert by someone pretending to be a roadie.

Kutzle says his eclectic background brings a certain energy and even a zany point of view to OneRepublic. He knows how to score music and that’s also helpful.

Ryan Tedder is the “top line” guy with the words and the melody, he says. “I come to the table with the oddball stuff. Because of my history I think left-of-centre. I’m the voice that has to be tamed.”

Like Tedder, who is always involved in one side project after another, Kutzle has also branched out. He’s part of a band called Monarch, which has recorded an EP called Apollo.

Kutzle’s also a bit of a loner. On the day of the interview Kutzle, was in his RV with his wife, a river rafting guide, overlooking the Pacific Ocean. Some of his mates were at Coachella, the massive music festival in Indio, California, but Kutzle says he’s not into crowds like that.

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

“I’ve got a few mikes and guitars around and I am vibing off the atmosphere. RV. When I was a kid, my grandparents had a camper and I’d always climb into it.”

OneRepublic is on a hiatus from almost two years of touring in support of their 2013 album Native, which sold more than 100,000 copies in Canada. But that doesn’t mean they aren’t working.

They were just in Tedder’s studio in Denver for a month, working on music for a new album. Kutzle hopes it will be out in early 2016.

And that work will continue on their Canadian tour. “Our best work comes when we are on tour. What else do you do during the day?”

OneRepublic

Where: Canadian Tire Centre

When: April 21 at 7:30 p.m.

Tickets:capitaltickets.ca
